events.title: Defense Submits Touhy Requests After Epstein's Death
events.description: Attorney Michael C. Miller, on behalf of Epstein's estate, submits formal document requests (Touhy requests) to the SDNY, Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), and FBI, seeking information related to Epstein's death.

events.title: Epstein's Death and Subsequent Legal Requests
events.description: The email chain discusses the ongoing handling of document requests from Epstein's defense team following his death, indicating the criminal proceeding is no longer pending.

keyFacts: Following Jeffrey Epstein's death, his defense attorneys immediately began submitting formal document requests (Touhy requests) to government agencies including the SDNY, MCC, and FBI.

The U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) internally debated how to handle these posthumous requests, questioning whether criminal AUSAs were the appropriate point of contact and suggesting referral to the Civil Division.
The defense legal team included attorneys Michael C. Miller, Reid Weingarten, Martin G. Weinberg, Jason Meade, and Michael Scavelli from Steptoe & Johnson LLP.
The correspondence indicates there was 'no proceeding' pending related to Epstein's death at the time, highlighting the unusual legal situation created by his death while in custody.
The document shows coordination between Epstein's defense team and government prosecutors even after Epstein's death, regarding evidentiary requests.
